Question Why do we study Fourier transforms? A: Fourier transforms are used in: designing electrical circuits signal processing, analysis (deﬁned for all t) image processing · · · solving diﬀerential equations. Remark Fourier transforms can be derived either as a generalization of Fourier series, or as a special case of Laplace transforms. We ﬁrst use the former direction. TSF - FOURIER TRANSFORMS MATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Deﬁnition Let f (t) be a function of t. The Fourier transform F[f (t)] = F (ω) is deﬁned as F (ω) = F[f (t)] = 1 √ 2π ∫ ∞ −∞ f (t)e −iωtdt. NB F is a function of a real variable ω (omega) f and F are in general complex F (ω) = F[f (t)] is like a 2-sided Laplace transform (i.e., starting at −∞) with s = iω F (ω) exists if f (t) and all its derivatives −→ 0 as t −→ ±∞. TSF - FOURIER TRANSFORMS MATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Question How do we get the inverse Fourier transform? Theorem Fourier Inversion Theorem At points where f (t) is continuous, f (t) = 1 √ 2π ∫ ∞ −∞ F (ω)e iωtdω = F −1[F (ω)], where F (ω) = 1√2π ∫ ∞ −∞ f (t)e −iωtdt = F[f (t)]. TSF - FOURIER TRANSFORMS MATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Hence Deﬁnition The inverse Fourier transform of F (ω) is deﬁned to be f (t) = 1 √2π ∫ ∞ −∞ F (ω)e iωtdω under suitable conditions of continuity. At ﬁnite discontinuities the integral expression converges to the midpoint of the jump, i.e., 1 2[f (t +) + f (t −)] = 1 √2π ∫ ∞ −∞ F (ω)e iωtdω. Question: How do we explain this? TSF - FOURIER TRANSFORMS MATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) The function f (t) we obtain after applying the inverse Fourier transform theorem is the same as the original function whenever the function is continuous. So what happens when there is a “jump”? e.g., a jump at x = a. TSF - FOURIER TRANSFORMS MATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) A: Then the inverse Fourier transform equals the value that is “HALF WAY”, i.e., ﬁnd the value as you approach x = a from the left and the value as you approach x = a from the right. Add them up and divide by 2. e.g., From the left: 1 From the right: 3 Hence half way is 1+3 2 = 2, so at t = 2, we say f (2) = 2. TSF - FOURIER TRANSFORMS MATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Recall A function f is even if f (−x) = f (x), e.g., y = x 2, y = cos x. A function f is odd if f (−x) = −f (x), e.g., y = x, y = x 3, y = sin x. Remark Odd function × or ÷ odd function is even Odd function × or ÷ even function is odd Even function × or ÷ even function is even If f (t) is an even function, then ∫ a −a f (t)dt = 2 ∫ a 0 f (t)dt. If f (t) is an odd function, then ∫ a −a f (t)dt = 0. TSF - FOURIER TRANSFORMS MATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Remark We use Fourier transforms and inverse Fourier transforms in ﬁnding various integrals. Example Let f (t) = (1 − t)[H(t) − H(t − 1)] = { 1 − t, 0 < t < 1 0, otherwise Find F (ω) and sketch the function to which the inverse transform converges. Deduce that ∫ ∞ 0 1−cos ω ω2 dω = π 2 and evaluate ∫ ∞ 0 sin 1 2 ω ω dω. TSF - FOURIER TRANSFORMS MATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Solution Since f (t) = { 1 − t, 0 < t < 1 0, otherwise, by deﬁnition and integration by parts, we get F (ω) = 1 √2π ∫ ∞ −∞ e −iωtf (t)dt = 1 √2π ∫ 1 0 e −iωt(1 − t)dt = 1 √2π [(1 − t)e −iωt −iω − (−1) e −iωt (−iω)2 ]1 0 = 1 √2π [0 − e −iω ω2 − ( −1 iω − 1 ω2 )] = 1 √2π [ 1 ω2 − i ω − e −iω ω2 ] . TSF - FOURIER TRANSFORMS MATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Solution (continued...) We now apply the inverse Fourier transform to get back to f (t): f (t) = 1 √ 2π ∫ ∞ −∞ e iωtF (ω)dω = 1 √ 2π ∫ ∞ −∞ ( e iωt 1 √2π [ 1 ω2 − i ω − e −iω ω2 ]) dω = 1 2π ∫ ∞ −∞ e iωt ( 1 ω2 − i ω − e −iω ω2 ) dω at all points of continuity. TSF - FOURIER TRANSFORMS MATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Solution (continued...) We now wish to deduce that ∫ ∞ 0 1 − cos ω ω2 dω = π 2 . Recall that f (t) = { 1 − t, 0 < t < 1 0, otherwise, has a jump at t = 0. At t = 0, we go half way at the “jump” and we use the value 0+1 2 = 1 2, i.e., inverse Fourier transform converges to 1 2. Hence f (0) = 1 2 = 1 2π ∫ ∞ −∞ e 0 ( 1 ω2 − i ω − e −iω ω2 ) dω. TSF - FOURIER TRANSFORMS MATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Solution (continued...) Recall that e −iω = cos(−ω) + i sin(−ω) = cos ω − i sin ω. Therefore, 1 2 = 1 2π ∫ ∞ −∞ ( 1 ω2 − i ω − cos ω − i sin ω ω2 ) dω, i.e., π = ∫ ∞ −∞ ( 1 ω2 − i ω − cos ω − i sin ω ω2 ) dω. TSF - FOURIER TRANSFORMS MATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Solution (continued...) Question How do we get ∫ ∞ −∞ 1−cos ω ω2 dω? A: Equating real parts, we get π = ∫ ∞ −∞ 1 − cos ω ω2 dω. Recall that we want ∫ ∞ 0 1 − cos ω ω2 dω. Note that 1 − cos ω and ω2 are even functions. Therefore, 1−cos ω ω2 is even. TSF - FOURIER TRANSFORMS MATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Solution (continued...) It follows that π = 2 ∫ ∞ 0 1 − cos ω ω2 dω and so ∫ ∞ 0 1 − cos ω ω2 dω = π 2 , as desired. TSF - FOURIER TRANSFORMS MATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Solution (continued...) We now need to ﬁnd ∫ ∞ 0 sin ω 2 ω dω. In the above, we used t = 0. We can use a diﬀerent value of t. What t shall we use? From “ ω 2 ”, we can try t = 1 2. At t = 1 2, f is continuous and so f (1 2 ) = 1 − 1 2 = 1 2 . Using inverse Fourier transform, we get 1 2 = 1 2π ∫ ∞ −∞ e iω· 1 2 ( 1 ω2 − i ω − e −iω ω2 ) dω. TSF - FOURIER TRANSFORMS MATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Solution (continued...) Therefore, π = ∫ ∞ −∞ ( e i ω 2 ω2 − ie i ω 2 ω − e −i ω 2 ω2 ) dω. Recall that sin ϕ = eiϕ−e−iϕ 2i . Thus, e i ω 2 ω2 − e −i ω 2 ω2 = 1 ω2 2i sin ω 2 . It follows that π = ∫ ∞ −∞ ( 2i ω2 sin ω 2 − ie i ω 2 ω ) dω and so TSF - FOURIER TRANSFORMS MATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Solution (continued...) π = ∫ ∞ −∞ 2i ω2 sin ω 2 − i ω (cos ω 2 + i sin ω 2 ) dω = ∫ ∞ −∞ ([ 2 ω2 sin ω 2 − 1 ω cos ω 2 ] i + sin ω 2 ω ) dω. Equating real parts, we get π = ∫ ∞ −∞ sin ω 2 ω dω. Notice that sin ω 2 and ω are both odd functions and so sin ω 2 ω is an even function. TSF - FOURIER TRANSFORMS MATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Solution (continued...) It follows that π = 2 ∫ ∞ 0 sin ω 2 ω dω so that ∫ ∞ 0 sin ω 2 ω dω = π 2 . TSF - FOURIER TRANSFORMS MATH2014 : MATHEMATICS II (Engineering) Remark Recall the convolution for Laplace transforms (f ∗ g )(t) = ∫ t 0 f (u)g (t − u)du and L[f ∗ g ] = F (s)G (s). What about for Fourier transforms? Convolution for Fourier transforms We have another convolution for FT denoted by ∗2 and given as f ∗2 g = ∫ ∞ −∞ f (u)g (t − u)du and F[f ∗2 g ] = √2πF[f ]F[g ] = √2πF (ω)G (ω).
